title: 111_hr2855
content: The Act may be cited as the "Drug Overdose Reduction Act". The Congress finds that drug overdose deaths have become a significant public health issue, with a 400% increase in accidental drug overdose deaths between 1980 and 1999. Additionally, 95% of unintentional poisoning deaths are due to drugs. In the year 2000, poisoning deaths cost society over $25 billion in total, with most drug-related deaths involving multiple drugs including opioids and alcohol. Community-based programs have successfully prevented opioid overdose deaths through education and access to naloxone, an effective opioid antagonist. Public health programs in major cities and states distribute naloxone to prevent drug overdoses, with successful outcomes saving lives. Training witnesses to respond effectively to overdoses is crucial for prevention programs. Overdose prevention programs are necessary in correctional facilities, addiction treatment programs, and other high-risk environments after a period of abstinence. The text chunk "SEC. 3. OVERDOSE PREVENTION GRANT PROGRAM." is a condensed summary of the previous information about the importance of overdose prevention programs in various high-risk environments. SEC. 3. OVERDOSE PREVENTION GRANT PROGRAM. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will award grants to eligible entities to reduce drug overdose deaths. Entities must submit applications detailing activities and capacity to receive funding. Priority is given in awarding grants. The Director will prioritize public health agencies and community-based organizations with expertise in preventing drug overdose deaths in high-risk populations for grants. Eligible entities must agree to use the funding for activities like distributing naloxone and training responders on overdose response. The funding provided will be used for overdose prevention programs, treatment, and response for individuals in need. Eligible entities must submit a report on the results of the activities supported by the grant. $27,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2011, with additional funding for 2012 to 2014. SEC. 4. SENTINEL SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will compile and publish annual data on fatal and nonfatal drug overdoses, collected from various sources including county, State, tribal, and private entities. The data will be accessible to the public online and will include details on the drugs involved in fatal overdoses, trends in polydrug use, toxicology screenings, and emerging overdose patterns. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will compile annual data on fatal and nonfatal drug overdoses, including details on drugs involved, polydrug use trends, toxicology screenings, and overdose patterns. State medical examiners will identify drugs involved in fatal and nonfatal unintentional poisonings, along with the demographics of victims. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2010 and 2011, with additional funding for 2012 through 2014. SEC. 5. SURVEILLANCE CAPACITY BUILDING. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will provide grants to improve drug overdose surveillance capabilities, including enhancing toxicological screenings, training for identifying overdose causes, hiring analysts, and purchasing surveillance resources. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will provide grants for drug overdose surveillance and reporting. State, local, or tribal governments must submit an application demonstrating their capacity to carry out funded activities. Recipients must prepare and submit a report within 90 days of the grant or cooperative agreement. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will provide grants for drug overdose surveillance and reporting. Recipients must submit a report within 90 days of the grant period. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2010 and 2011, with additional funding for 2012 through 2014. SEC. 6. REDUCING OVERDOSE DEATHS. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention must develop a plan within 180 days to reduce drug overdose deaths, including identifying data barriers, implementing prevention strategies, analyzing drug sources, and recommending improvements to overdose prevention programs. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention must develop a plan within 180 days to reduce drug overdose deaths, including identifying data barriers, implementing prevention strategies, analyzing drug sources, and recommending improvements to overdose prevention programs. The plan should include recommendations for legislative or administrative action and involve stakeholders directly impacted by drug overdose. Stakeholders include individuals at-risk of overdose, service providers, advocates, and organizations with expertise in drug overdose. SEC. 7. OVERDOSE PREVENTION RESEARCH. The Director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse prioritizes research on drug overdose and prevention. Research includes examining overdose circumstances, identifying drugs involved, evaluating prevention programs, and developing naloxone dosage forms for laypersons and first responders. Authorization of $5,000,000 for fiscal years 2010-2011 and additional funding for 2012-2014 for prehospital treatment of unintentional drug overdose. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Director" refers to the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The term "drug" includes any controlled substance. An "eligible entity" is defined as a State, local, or tribal government, a correctional institution, a law enforcement agency, a community agency, or a private nonprofit organization. The term "State" refers to any of the several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, or the Northern. Training is defined as educational, instructional, or consultative activities, including volunteer trainings, awareness building exercises, outreach to at-risk individuals for drug overdose, and distribution of educational materials.
